Invigoratingly action-packed, exuberantly written, and vividly performed, Mad Max: Fury Road presents potentiality and excitement for an upcoming franchise - and this beginning sure serves as a grandiose fresh start. 4/4.

A flat out action-fest. A two hour car chase, or maybe more accurately tank/car/motocycle/semi/vehiclewithwheels chase. But a great one. Tom Hardy may get top billing, but Charlize Theron feels like the protagonist of the movie with Hardy's Max being a close second. 

Having never seen the original Mad Max films, I was not sure what to expect, but it played out pretty much how I expected from the trailers and clips I had seen. Take a movie that goes over the top on outrageous costumes, sets and action sequences, and then ramp that up to 11. That should be a pretty good idea of what to expect with this movie. For example, when we first meet the women that Max is trying to help free, they are removing chastity belts that literally have razor sharp teeth on them. There is a post-nuclear fallout mutant that plays a flame-shooting guitar nonstop in front of a giant wall of speakers attached to a war vehicle. Everytime they came up with a concept or idea, I feel like they said "That is great! But can we make it bigger, or crazier."

Hardy's Max is a quiet hero, with a touch of insanity that never gets fully explored. Maybe that character trait is being saved for a sequel. I think he says a total of 40 words throughout the film. But it works. Theron is a hardened road warrior (wink wink) that is trying to balance out the horrors that were done to her. She does a great job with this and comes across as a strong determined leader.
If you are looking for an action movie this is it. This is the number one movie of the year. This is what I was looking for in a movie.

Somehow they take a 2 hour car chase and make a pretty entertaining movie out of it. The costumes and vehicles make this movie worth it. They overdo the 3D thing toward the end, but I guess at least they use the 3D to throw things at you, but you know me.... I saw it traditional. Well worth the 2 hours of my life! Go see this in the theater, where it was designed to be seen! No stinger.

INTENSE!!! If I had to sum up this film with just one word. A high-octane, no frills, no BS thrill ride that doesn't let up. What I love about this film is that George Miller lets the action move the plot of the story. The premise is a simple one; like the previous Mad Max films, and serves to move the action along. Tom Hardy is awesome, as usual, the guy had like 10 lines in the whole film but I found couldn't take my eyes off him. Charlize Theron was just as badass as Tom Hardy in the film. In a lot of ways it's really her character's film, and Max is just along for the ride helping out. I really liked her character...but Mad Max films are not character films, they're action films. I can honestly say the action in this film is one the best I've seen in a LONG LONG time. This is most likely going to be the must see movie of the 2015 summer movie season. I enjoyed this film way better than the Avengers, and I'm a comic book nerd. Highly recommend this flick!!!

Is Mad Max: Fury Road the best movie I've ever seen?  Maybe not, but is it the best action movie I've ever seen?  Quite possibly. 

Growing up a fan of the original trilogy, I was of course, excited to hear there would be another installment and by the original Writer/Director no less.  This time we get to see the true picture of what George Miller envisioned 30 years ago with his classics that were made with a fraction of the budget.  Fury Road doesn't confine itself in the typical "action movie" mold.  It feels bigger, somehow.  I mean, sure it's a huge over the top movie, but it feels like it's more than just your standard popcorn movie because at the heart it has a story to be told and its a good one.  

We get to see Max terrorized by his past, tortured and held captive until he escapes to join a band of refugees themselves.  At first we see him looking out for himself, knowing when he's gotten involved in the past, people always get hurt, himself included.  But yet again, Max begins to rally behind his fellow refugees.  It's a great character driven movie not only for Max, a man who has maybe a total of 3 or 4 lines, but for the women he is trying to help protect.  

So, as I said, Fury Road may not be the best movie ever made, but it sure tries and honestly, comes closer than its predecessors, which is saying something.  Fans will love it.  Everyone else will become fans.

Action movies haven't had a masterpiece in a long time. Many action movies today are very lazy and have jump cuts, obvious stunt people, and close up shots. But George Miller has swooped in to save the day.

Mad Max: Fury Road is a masterpiece, and will go down as one of the best action movies ever put to the big screen. I absolutely loved it. Everything in this movie was spectacular, and it's gonna be a great year if there is a movie that I love more than Mad Max: Fury Road.

This movie is phenomenal. The first big thing is what the trailer shows, the action. Some of the best action scenes ever filmed. Wide shots, no shaky cam, great practical effects, even better CGI effects, and fantastic characters. This movie is a non-stop thrill ride that I really want to see over and over again. This movie makes Fast & Furious look like Dumbo the Flying Elephant at Disney World. This movie is INSANE! There is a guy playing an electric guitar shooting fire out of it during the action scenes! There is a guy who drives a mix of a corvette and a tank! If that doesn't get you excited, you'll hate this movie. If it does excite you, you'll love it.

All of the actors did a fantastic job. Tom Hardy is great as Max. He doesn't have a lot of lines, but if you remember in Road Warrior, Mel Gibson only has somewhere around 20 lines in the whole movie. Charlize Theron was great as well. I thought she was the main character in the movie and she did a great job. But I thought the most interesting character was Nux, who was played by Nicholas Hoult, who is nearly unrecognizable in this role. He was my favorite character in the whole movie. I also thought the villains Immortan Joe(Hugh Keays-Byrne) and Rictus Erectus(Nathan Jones) were great as well. There was a awesome hand-to-hand combat fight between Rictus and Max that I wasn't expecting. The people in the land looked to Immortan Joe as a god, and I thought that he had a cool look and was a menacing villain.

One thing many will hate about the movie is the story. And while it may not be the greatest story of all time, it is serviceable for a movie like this. I won't say anything about it, but the movie isn't heavy on story, but it has one. I also, unlike most people, thought there was enough development as well. I thought that each character got enough development, and they honestly didn't need a lot to begin with.

One of the highest positive I can give this movie is the directing. George Miller is the true star of this movie. Miller, at the age of 70, does an action movie that action directors half his age wish they could do. Miller has so much experience directing action movies, and he knows how to utilize practical and CGI effects to his advantage. In my opinion, he is one of the best action directors in the world today. I don't know how many more movies he will do, but I hope he makes more Mad Max movies, because that is his bread and butter.

Overall, I think Mad Max: Fury Road is one of the best action films ever made. These are the movies that need to be made! A crazy action film that will put in insane things, but it doesn't matter because either way, you should love the movie if you love action movies. I would have to give Mad Max: Fury Road an A+. This is a film that you HAVE to see in the theater.......multiple times.
what an action pack from start to end .
Through a mix of magnificent visual effects, astonishing action sequences, and memorable characters, Mad Max: Fury Road gives us one of the best action films of all time.
Fantastic, non-stop thrill ride. Same good ole apocalyptic insanity that we remembered from the 80's, jammed packed with spectacular special effects! Must see in 3D.
this movie was Awesome! so unique and different movie for today's world and that's what makes it amazing. Definitely watching it more than once on the big screen
WHAT A LOVELY MOVIE!!!

Wow. What a blast. I really enjoyed this film! Director George Miller returns 30 years after Max Mad Beyond Thunderdome (1985). This time around Max is played by Tom Hardy. Hardy does a fantastic job going away from the more charasmatic performance of Mel Gibson and instead making Max his own. From his very little dialogue we once again get a reluctant hero that's thrown into a situation where he knows he must help. Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron) steals Immortan Joe's (Hugh Keays-Byrne who played Toecutter in the original 1979 film!) numerous young wives. The wives are there to make Joe a future warlord heir. He has tried countless times, but all his children have some sort of birth defect and just aren't strong enough. Furiosa takes them away and attempts to bring them back to her homeland where the grass is green and life is awaiting them. Joe sends out his men including The War Boys a group of young men who believe in Joe's fake promises and causes. Max is captured early on and links up with Furiosa and eventually realizes he has the ability to shoo away his own nightmares and perhaps redeem himself a bit by helping Furiosa and the young women. The film also co-stars Nicholas Hoult as Nux a War Boy who realizes something isn't quite right. The film uses a lot of practical effects. There's real cars chasing each other, things are really exploding. CGI is used sparingly and its a breath of fresh air. We don't get too much character development here (there's barely any dialogue), but through the characters actions we see their will to survive and what has to be done. The movie is essentially one long chase scene with just some crazy over the top moments that are a blast to see. A non stop action film! Hopefully, this does well and they make a couple more! Definitely, highly recommend giving this one a look!

Furiousa's Road: Mad Max

Fury road is the fourth installment in George Miller's Mad Max saga. This time around the titular character who used to be portrayed by Mel Gibson, has not been given to Tom Hardy. The film follows a car chase which their objective is to keep Immoten Joe's wives away from him.

First of all, this is definitely not Maxs story for the main character of this film is clearly Imperator Furiousa, who's determination and heroics set the course for the coolest action movie in recent memory. The character is brilliantly portrayed by Charlize Theron, proving she can do more serious roles. The action is mind blowing and fantastic. It is incredible in every sense of the word. The practical effects are jaw dropping, filled with flying cars, stunt work and gigantic explosions literally flying through the the screen. This plus a great percussion infused score by Hans Zimmer prot√É (C)g√É (C) Junkie XL. The story is also good, filled with emotional, funny, and surprising moments, but all in all the films biggest points are for its action and Miller's fantastic direction. This is how you make an action movie.

One small problem with the film was how Tom Hardys voice did not fit well with the sound mix. It felt more defined, as if he had rerecorded all the scenes he spoke in. It was distracting to see him character speak on screen. Another thing I found questionable was how he barely spoke, as an audience member who hasn't seen the previous 3, I am not sure if he is supposed to be a man of few words, even Nicholas Hoult, who was great in this film, has more lines than hardy, the titular character.

This film was great, it surprised me as a person who was not very engaged by the trailers. Though It was actually Furiousa's story, it was still very enjoyable. Mad max's character had some development problems but the film remained crazy, over the top, and beautiful. This is how action should be made. And it takes a 70 year old to get it done right. 

Rating: 8.4 (A-)

This type of movie isn't really my thing, but I'm glad that I saw this. It isn't the action masterpiece that people keep saying that it is, but it definitely is both fun and well made. Surprisingly well made, actually. I have only seen the first Mad Max, but to be honest, this movie seems to stand on its own. Despite its simple plot and characters that are either cardboard cutouts or fully fleshed-out human beings, Mad Max: Fury Road is beautiful chaos. It's just self-aware enough to embrace its insanity, and its 3D makes a great use of depth of field and create a fully immersive world. Going into this, I knew what I was getting myself into, but I still didn't really know how much I was going to like it. For a little while, I was a bit worried because the movie really throws itself into the thick of things right away. It's a little jarring at first and takes some time to find its feet (or, uh, tires... I apologize), but it's still of such a grand scale that even when it doesn't quite work, it's still very interesting to watch. Its aesthetics are terrific, from production design to cinematography, and the film itself is very easy to appreciate from an artistic standpoint. The 3D actually isn't wasted and creates some really good depth of field, especially during scenes within canyons or ravines. Where the film isn't quite as sound, however, is its human core. For a while, virtually all characters are blank slates that are hard to sympathize for (beyond an instinctual level) or identify with. It isn't really until the halfway mark that the characters are given interesting things to do, and what they do seem fitting and understandable. Charlize Theron does great work throughout and her character is such a badass and break from the norm (i.e.: she's a strong female character in a traditionally masculine setting), and the other female characters, while initially seeming to be just token victims, find their chance to shine. It's just that that's a little too late. The character-driven moments are still effective and refreshing, but they could have been expanded upon, especially given that this movie is otherwise a two-hour chase scene. The weirdest thing, though, is how I just didn't care about the titular character. Max himself is cool to watch, but isn't necessarily as interesting as the rest. It's not Charlize Theron's fault that she overshadows Tom Hardy--it's the script's fault. It's just that given his being more or less the central character, it made me feel like the film was slightly unfocused in terms of whose story it wanted to tell. That isn't a deal breaker, though, since Charlize Theron's character is great. As an action movie, Mad Max: Fury Road is alarmingly artistic in its execution, even if it could have done more with its characters for the first half balanced itself out a little more equally. It's like a heavy metal opera with Cirque du Soleil performers, and you have to admit, that's interesting whether you particularly like action movies or not (I, personally fall into the latter category). With its bonkers set pieces to behold and refreshing--but never in-your-face--feminist themes, this is an action movie that even the snootiest of moviegoers can get behind. 8/10, really good, one thumb up, above average, etc.

We're told by Max himself that his world is fire. I have to agree, but I also have to add that his world is beautiful and viciously insane. Mad Max: Fury Road is a thirty year old sequel that feels like it was thirty years in the making. But we finally have it, and it is glorious. The film simply follows a chase between the War Boys and Max as they race across the Wasteland. So many production delays and hold ups started to make me a little worried. And then the reviews started pouring in, and that 98% popped up...and stayed...and stayed. This film deserves every bit of praise it can possibly get. And the best part of all? This is, 100%, the director's vision without any studio interference. To explain what that means would be to spoil certain aspects, so I'll refrain. For starters, the film is simply gorgeous to look at. The over saturated and contrasting oranges and blues are stunning, especially in the wide shots. And despite the world being a lot of oranges, reds, and browns, everything still manages to have a special pop to it. Acting wise, everyone seemed to understand the insanity they signed up for, and they roll with it. And then there's Tom Hardy and Charlize Theron. Hardy gives us a new take on Max while respecting the legacy of the character, and he nails it. But Theron really shines, and certainly steals the film in some parts. The entire film feels like it was ripped from the 1980s, and it is an absolute blast. And, shockingly, the 3D was actually put to really good use. The colors pop, the car parts fly, but there are some scenes where the locales are given incredible depth. Do yourself a favor, go see this film, and have yourself a lovely day.

Where to start with a movie that was packed with only great things? Mad Max Fury Road was incredible in every single way!! I was mesmerized by the trailer and hoped that it would exceed even the trailer. Man did it exceed that! To start, the special effects and cinematography together was mind blowing! It's absolutely beautiful and really nice to look at. It's a love letter to the eyes. The story is about Max being captured and helping Furiosa send a group of women to safety. The characters are really strongly built. I adored all the characters in Fury Road, there wasn't a single character I didn't like. The protagonists were strong and the villain was perfect. The villain was super menacing and he wasn't like a sit down villain at all, he got down to business. The action scenes were absolutely the best part of the movie. There was nonstop action from beginning to end. There was a perfect amount of suspense and action, it's not overdone at all. In fact I wanted this movie to be longer with how much I loved these scenes. Any scene in this film caused edge of seat suspense and caused me to sweat even. These characters kick butt to the extreme, they aren't afraid to act bravely. I really got attached to the characters emotionally too. Furiosa and even Nux I felt for, they both had a sad mission to achieve that seems like it was near impossible at the time even if someone's did. The death of the villains felt super satisfying the way that they went down. There's not enough great things I can say that I haven't really covered. Everything is really top notch in every aspect. Mad Max Fury Road is super intense, well acted and even has an emotional pull! Exceeded my already high expectations! A

Mad Max is exactly what is should be, a great action film with fantastic performances and a spectacular visual look. For once in his life, Tom Hardy is the weakest actor out of the three main characters. He did a good job as Max but unfortunately he seemed to jut be going through the motions. Fortunately however, this movie has the always impressive Charlize Theron as Furiosa, and Nicholas Hoult gives his best performance as Nux. Nux is the most interesting and intense character in this movie and I wish it was him and Max the whole film. But for now, this will do. 
There isn't much story to this film and I wasn't expecting there to be. I was very pleased with the films conclusion. Hardly any CGI and it is so refreshing to see no shaky cam in an action movie. Too bad the lack of story and character development took this one down a few notches. 
In conclusion, great action scenes and visuals, two good and one great performance by Nicholas Hoult (seriously I would nominate for best supporting actor), but not a lot of story and poor character development. 3/5 and I will buy it on blu ray. I recommend to those who like action movies but not who are looking for a deep action film. 

P.S. The "what a lovely day" Line is my second favorite line of the year behind Colin Firth's line in the church in Kingsman.

"Holy Smokes! "Mad Max: Fury Road" is a perfect summer movie. It blew me out of my seat."
Movie Review: Mad Max: Fury Road
Date Viewed: May 20 2015
Directed By George Miller (Mad Max, Max Max 2: The Road Warrior, Mad Max Beyond Thunderdome, Happy Feet, Lorenzo's Oil and Babe: Pig in the City)
Written By George Miller, Brendan McCarthy and Nico Lathouris
Starring: Tom Hardy, Charlize Theron, Hugh Keays-Byrne, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, Nicholas Hoult, Riley Keough, Abbey Lee, Zoe Kravitz, Courtney Eatin, John Howard, Richard Carter, Jennifer Hagan, Angus Sampson and Melissa Jaffer.

30 years after his last adventure, Mad Max is back in what may be the best action movie in years, "Mad Max: Fury Road". It makes "Avengers: Age of Ultron" look like "Winnie the Pooh". It's a shame that Mel Gibson isn't back as the road warrior but he's replaced by one of the best actors working today, Tom Hardy. Yes, it has the name Mad Max in it's title, but it's not really his movie. The movie belongs to Charlize Theron as Imperator Furiosa, she's fierce, brutal and full of grit. Theron showed true dedication to the role by shaving her head and putting on a mechanical arm. Her great bad-ass performance can be compared to Sigourney Weaver in "Aliens" and Linda Hamilton in "Terminator 2". Theron and Hardy are great together as they go for a wild two-hour ride to Fury Road.

When we think about summer films, they're usually by-the-numbers. Lots of explosions, funny one-liners and the women are usually second-fiddle to the male characters. In every summer movie season, it's usually dominated by superheroes, apes, street racers, mutants and Transformers. "Mad Max: Fury Road" is a perfect summer movie. It may be a wild car chase movie but story and character remain front and center in "Fury Road". As the movie begins, we see Max Rockatansky (Hardy) being chased by the War Boys. After he gets captured, the War Boys use him as a blood bag for War Boy Nux (Nicholas Hoult).

Just like in the first three "Mad Max" movies, "Fury Road" is set in a post-apocalyptic future where the world has become a desert wasteland. The movie's villain is Immortan Joe played by Hugh Keays-Byrne, remember him? He was also Toecutter in the original Mad Max. Immortan Joe is the tyrannical cult leader of the War Boys. When five of his wives (who were specially selected for breeding) go missing, he sends his entire army to go after Imperator Furiosa (Theron) who has his wives hidden in her heavily armoured War Rig.

Nux joins the pursuit with Max strapped to the hood of his car. After a powerful sand storm sends the car flying off the road, Max breaks free from his chains and joins Furiosa on the road to escape from Joe's army of War Boys and thugs. She plans on going to the "Green Place", a place she remembers from her youth. Max is still haunted by the deaths of his wife and daughter and he's now a virtual loner in this dystopian wasteland. Joe's five wives (Toast, Angharad, Capable, The Dag and Cheedo) have different personalities and they don't want their children to be warlords just like him. The five women are played by Rosie Huntington-Whiteley (Transformers: Dark of the Moon), Zoe Kravitz, Courtney Eaton, Riley Keough and Abbey Lee Kershaw. Nicholas Hoult is really good as Nux, the War Boy who utters the movie's tagline, "WHAT A LOVELY DAY!". Hugh Keays-Byrne's brutal Immortan Joe is just as menacing and sadistic as his Toecutter was in the original "Mad Max" which came out in 1979.

Director George Miller must've had lovely days when he made "Mad Max: Fury Road" because it is extravagant action movie making at it's best. The stunts are some of the best I've ever seen, the cinematography by John Seale (The English Patient) is beautiful to look at, the score by Junkie XL is dynamite, and Miller even brought his wife, Margaret Sixel, to the editing room. After making family movies like "Babe: Pig in the City" and "Happy Feet", George Miller has made one of the most daring summer blockbusters in recent memory. There are no green-screens or special effects in "Fury Road", Miller wanted to keep his mad vision real.

"Mad Max: Fury Road" blew me out of my seat, it's one of the best action movies ever made.

Most of the film uses practical effects making this one of the most believable looking action films of the past decade; this is one of the best action films of the past decade. Let's not forget that the film is surprisingly stuffed with a ton of narrative heft. Michael Bay, you should be taking notes from Mr. Miller.

A visual treat from start to finish!  The costumes, the stunts, the action...every scene just bursts with vitality. Not to forget the sound...wow!!  This is what the cinema is made for!  Great to have this franchise back on our screens but it could've just done with being 15 minutes shorter.
Truly enjoyed it. Excited for more.

In an era of too much CGI and needless story elements, this was a refreshing return to eye-popping, mind boggling action. 

My only complaint was there were a few "just for 3-D" moments that were unnecessary. 

Tom Hardy is matter-of-fact as "Max" (is that his name? He didn't seem 100% sure, which leads to fun speculation). Charlize Theron is the true star: the pedal to the medal driving force behind the action. 

Memorable characters and scenes that stay with you days after. The Mad Max series is a gift to the action genre, and this fits on perfectly, somewhere.
The return of the Road Warrior, thankfully not the Thunderdome.

BY FAR; one of the greatest action films I've ever seen. 2 Hours of practical effects based car-chases; it's action porn. However, considering the glimpse of strong plot and characters, I actually wish there were a little more effort put into those.

Absolute garbage.  The only remarkable aspect of this production might be how the marketing department managed to fool so many people they were in for some sort of progressive feminist action flick.  It is not.
One of the best action packed movies of this 2010-2020 decade! Furiosa is a badass chick and Max is good in this intense movie
Great, awesome film. Nonstop action. Better then the original. Will watch it again.

I hate starting my reviews straight to the point but I'm saying it, Mad Max: Fury Road is the best action movie I've seen in a long time. George Miller does an excellent job at bringing back the elements on what made The Road Warrior so great and pushes them up to the highest level. This film tells it's story through a visual style instead of hitting us with lines and lines of dialogue, and developing our characters not through exposition but instead through the actions our characters go through. Something that alway stands out to me is how beautiful this film is, there is one certain scene involving a sandstorm where I have to say it is one of the most beautiful moments I've seen in film. I loved Mad Max: Fury Road, the action is spectacular , it works with it's visual storytelling , and is a beautiful symphony of death, destruction and creativity.

150924: I've spent 24 hours thinking about this film and still find myself wondering what to say. Symphony of special effects comes to mind. Extravaganza of modified vehicles and violence. It seems to me that the first two Mad Max films had a story to them. I didn't really find this much of a story. Fight to escape, and then strangely enough, fight to return. That's about it. Am I over-valuing the first two films? This will be one of those DVDs one can buy spending hours reviewing all the small details missed the first time. And, there are a lot of small details in the characters and vehicles. So many, in fact, that I found myself constantly scanning the screen in an attempt to take them all in. The guy behind me kept holding his breath during the battle scenes. I thought he was going to pass out. Each time the action calmed for a second he took in this big breath. The action is non-stop and there are some endearing, if not enduring, characters. I won't give it more than four stars because it's nothing more than what I've stated. Reminds me a bit of Pacific Rim (2013). You won't be bored.
Gracias!!  Gracias, gracias...
this movie was to insane but good

Not as good as "The Road Warrior" but a close second and better than "Max Max" or "Thunderdome." The action in this fourth installment of the Mad Max series is an absolute knockout! My palms were sweating thought nearly the entire film. Besides director/creator George Miller's exciting direction and gorgeously stark photography by John Seale, who came out of retirement to shoot this film, I think the action greatly benefits from most of it happening in-camera and was not redone later with CGI. As good as CGI has gotten, there is no substitute for seeing someone actually fighting on top of a fast moving vehicle, or seeing a vehicle really wipe out. In this film, Max finds himself helping Charlize Theron in her plan to free the "wives" of Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne, who played Toecutter in the original Mad Max") in a stolen War Rig. Immortan Joe send all of his forces after them and the rest of the film is one long chase scene that never lets up. Nearly 15 years in the making, Miller had years to think about this film and story and it really shows in all the details (the man-powered wheel to raise and lower vehicle into the mountaintop former, the tattoos given to Max after his capture, the Doof Warrior with his fiery guitar, the steering wheel tree, to the War Boys' belief system ("May you always be chrome and shiny"). Lesser films might have taken up a great deal of time to dwell on these elements, but Miller fills his film with so many of them that he's created a vastly rich universe that could fill several movies (Miller has said he already has two more completed scripts). Tom Hardy steps into the Mad Max role that Mel Gibson made famous and does an adequate job. He lack's Gibson's charisma and even though his name is in the title, he has the film stolen out from under him by a new character, Imperator Furiosa, played by a one-armed Charlize Theron, who I've always thought was a fine actress despite her looking like a super model. Nicholas Hoult is also a standout in the film as a War Boy who ends up siding with Max and the escaping wives. The story was co-written by Brendan McCarthy, which I found interesting that he worked for British comic 2000AD back in the 70s before the original "Mad Max" film. What's interesting is that Judge Dredd, the most regular character to appear in 2000AD was occasionally set in the "Cursed Earth" which is an apocalyptic wasteland between the Mega Cities that line the east and west coast. In the cursed earth, it's a lawless land that's filled with mutants, crazies and assorted villainy, much like the world of Mad Max. I've never heard Miller mention 2000AD or the Cursed Earth, but I've always wondered about the connection and I found it interesting that a 2000AD illustrator found his way into this picture. But I digress. Fury Road really deserves to be considered an action classic and in an age when reboots and remakes are a dime a dozen, this is one of the few to actually live up to even surpasses it's predecessors.

This was Mad,Ferocious,Vicious,Hell Raising,Excellent,Bad Shit Crazy,Scorching,and so awesome in 3-D that I didn't want it to end,because the effects blew me away at a certain point to where my eyes widened and my jaw dropped.
George Miller has truly out done himself with this 4th installment.

It should be said right up front that MAD MAX: FURY ROAD is probably not a movie for everybody.  While there are certainly many things about it that are objectively and inarguably great, the overall impression it leaves on viewers will depend on one's tolerance for the baroque and the bizarre, because those are both present in spades.  If you can get past that (or perhaps embrace it), you will find a breathlessly entertaining chase picture that exudes creativity from every frame, and one that is kind of a marvel of action choreography.

Ostensibly a sequel to the original films about "Mad" Max Rockatansky (those being MAD MAX, THE ROAD WARRIOR, and MAD MAX BEYOND THUNDERDOME), writer/director George Miller's FURY ROAD requires no knowledge of the events of the previous films, as an opening voice-over from Max (Tom Hardy) more or less sets the stage for the audience.  The storyline, set in a post-apocalyptic future (some unknown number of years from now), sees Max abducted by a strange society in a desolate wasteland, a society lorded over by the sinister, always-masked Immortan Joe (Hugh Keays-Byrne), a despot who has positioned himself as a deity-figure, worshipped by the downtrodden people he has subjugated.  Max soon finds himself aligned with Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron), one of Joe's prized drivers who has rebelled against him and seeks to transport Joe's captive harem (Zo√´ Kravitz, Rosie Huntington-Whiteley, Riley Keough, Abbey Lee, and Courtney Eaton) to the "green place," a far off land of safety.  Immortan Joe leads a large force to go after them, and a merry chase ensues, putting Max in a position to do what he's meant for - help the innocent. 

While the specifics of the plot might sound complex, they're really not.  In fact, there's just barely enough plot to support the movie.  The characters are vividly-drawn, to be sure, and the narrative gets the job done, but let there be no mistake: easily 70% of the movie exists as a series of protracted chase/action sequences.  This will certainly please the action fans in the audience, but those looking for an engrossing plot will probably find it to be somewhat lacking.  That is not to say the movie is without substance, however, as there are some great ideas in play, particularly those pertaining to religious fanaticism and the role of women in society.  These notions are grace notes, though, not focal points. 

Tom Hardy tackles the unenviable position of carrying the torch that made Mel Gibson a star, but he more than acquits himself.  His Max is a man of relatively few words, so Hardy brings an intense (and even quirky) physical presence to the part.  And while his character's stoicism is a defining feature, Hardy is able to mine some quite potent (though subtle) humor just from his body language and facial expressions.  Max may be the titular character, but Charlize Theron sort of upstages him (in a good way), and it is her journey that most people will come out of the movie thinking about.  It's a spectacular performance, one that should cement Theron as a viable action badass.  She conveys a steely-eyed, tough persona, someone who's dedicated to her mission to help Immortan Joe's captive girls, and as the movie goes on, Theron peels back the hard-edged layers to reveal a very human woman underneath.  Anybody out there who thinks that a woman can't be a believable action star (these people do exist, unfortunately) should be silenced by Theron's work here.

The aforementioned action is absolutely worth the price of admission.  The scale of the setpieces is kind of staggering; when you consider that director Miller is 70, it's remarkable that the filmmaking on display is so vital, visceral, and energized.  There are shots in this movie where easily twenty vehicles are in the frame, moving at high speeds, and interacting with practical explosion effects and stunt work, and it's incredible to watch.  Of course there are digital elements in play, as well, but the sheer amount of for-real staging and choreography is stunning.  Special kudos have to go to the stunt team, because they've pulled off something pretty special with their work here.

Where - if anywhere - does the movie go wrong?  As good as the action is, a case could be made that there's a little too much of it!  The movie barrels along at such a frenetic, nonstop pace (there are few quiet moments between the characters) that there does come a point by the third act where the setpieces - fun as they may be - reach a kind of exhausting level.  You will feel put through the wringer by the end of it all; for some, this will make the movie feel all the more satisfying, like stuffing yourself on a great meal, but for others it might be too much to take.  The movie also skirts right up to the edge of being a little too willfully weird; the design of Immortan Joe, his people, and their society is decidedly off-kilter, and it could be seen as strangeness just for the sake of it.  The performances of Theron and Hardy keep things grounded in a very relatable emotional context, but everything around them is quite unhinged, to say the very least; this is a film where a caravan of war vehicles is led by a (seemingly?) blind electric guitarist (whose guitar can double as a flame thrower, because why not?) who plays from the top of a tanker truck in the midst of the intense action.  If that sounds like your kind of weirdness, you're all set; if not, at least you've been warned. 

Ultimately, though, the movie is too handsomely made (I didn't even get to touch on the outstanding makeup and costumes, nor the saturated and rich cinematography, nor the thundering sound mix), and too engagingly directed and performed to dismiss.  You have not seen vehicular mayhem and stunts on this level in a long time (perhaps ever), and it's an undeniably personal vision from George Miller, one well worth experiencing.

A+  At this point with so many bloated bad actions movie coming out we really had no more faith that a GREAT action film would come without it being Marvel. With this forth-installment being put on the big screen. Mad Max: Fury Road is the best movie I have seen all year and one of the best action films of all time. This film takes all problems that people have with action films and makes everything right again and how it's supposed to be. My only tiny complain is that the story's concentrates on Theron character and Mad Max is just shoehorned to the story. With just that, George Miller gives us a deadly, edge of year seet thrill ride with beautuful wide shots ehere we know what are heroes are doing and no shakey camera that it's so fun to watch and enjoy. Miller built these action sets on practical effects which makes the film better and you just aopratiate that there is no CGI to be found because the action and suspense feel real and intense we care about these heroes, we can realte to them and we want to watch them succeed. The movie is a mind-blowing masterpiece that makes the perfecf action flicb that should have been made. This movie is also nuts with a guy playing an electric guitar with flames shooting out of it's neck. Everything you want in a GREAT and BADASS action film, this movie has the perfect practial and real action that shots that leave you with your mouth dropping of how awesome it is, likeable and relatable heroes, no shakey camera, entertaing and menacing enough villian. This is by far the best movie I have seen all year and absolutley worth watching.

best max movie. so much fun to watch

"My name is Max. My world is fire and blood."

'Mad Max: Fury Road' is the 4th instalment in mastermind, George Miller's insane post apocalyptic journey. Starring Charlize Theron (Monster, Hancock) Tom Hardy (The Dark Knight Rises) Nicholas Hoult (About a Boy) and (Hugh Kaeys-Byrn) as the movies villain Immortan Joe.

Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron) is assigned to a mission. The mission is to drive the war rig and go through to the next town and syphon gasoline. Furiosa ends up double crossing Immortan Joe and stealing his 5 wives to take them back to her homeland where they can be safe. Along side her is Max, a man of action and very few words. Together they must fight trough hordes of enemies in what is basically a 2 hour long, high speed chase.

I have been waiting since I heard about the green lighting of this movie back in 2009. I have been waiting for almost 6 years for this thing. My hype was high, I wasn't sure it would live up to my expectations. Well I am here to tell you that it did. It lived up to the hype, AND THEN SOME. This movie is absolutely, 1000% insane. What you saw in the trailers wasn't even close to the level of crazy shit that goes down in this movie. You know this movie is pretty much just all out, balls to the wall action, so if you think the trailers maybe showed off a little too much. You couldn't be more wrong.

The stunt work is choreographed and directed to perfection, it is the most well crafted and stunning movie I've ever seen and will probably ever see, which is kind of the norm and what to expect with a George Miller movie. There's explosions going off everywhere, cars blowing up left, right and centre, people being killed and blown to shreds. But none of it is convoluted, it all streams together perfectly, you know what is happening, when it happens. The fact that pretty much 90% of this movie is all practical effects and all stunt work is mind blowing. The cars that explode, that's happening. People bouncing from one side to the other on long poles at 60mph, picking people up and flying then back across, that's going down, too. Too many blockbusters these days are filled with CGI. And even with limitless amounts of stuff you can do with all of that. NONE of it even is even comparable to the action in this movie. The shit that goes down here, other movies couldn't even dream to aspire towards such a spectacle.

People complain that there's not much of a story, they wanted more. Well I gotta tell you, the story is just what it needs. For something to be great it doesn't need to be a vibrant cohesive piece of art. The story is very simple, and the simplicity of it is what makes it great. There's enough story to keep you paying attention to it and not just going in for explosions. Not to mention that It's not driven through its narrative or its dialogue. It's driven by its characters and its action. To which people also said they were underdeveloped and weren't written very well, from my stand point they absolutely were.

The character of Nux (Nicholas Hoult) was developed amazingly well, I didn't really expect to see much from him but he really became his own in this movie. He was developed enough to make you care, he was written to be understandable in his actions and he was by far, for me, one of the best things about the movie. Furiosa was also developed just enough to make you feel something for her character. She's one of the only good left in a world full of bad. What Miller does in this movie is make characters that not only do you are for but are also incredibly likeable and super bad ass. Max wasn't developed as much as some of the others but let's face it. If you've watched the older ones (which I recommend you do) There really isn't much to him. He's a man that's had everything taken from him and he has nothing left to lose. All he wants is to be left in peace. That's all he's every been and that's all he wants to carry on being.

What I also love about this movie is that the lead character is a woman. Hollywood these days are always depicting women who need a man take care of them. That they can't live without men. That is DEFINITELY not the case with this movie. Furiosa is fierce, she's skilled, she's unpredictable and she's all out bad ass. This is a testosterone filled movie but it's not the testosterone that takes charge.

Action movies these days aren't normally as good as one of the reasons being is that the hero is never really in any really danger. If he's never in danger or near death how can you possible expect to have your audience on the edge of their seats. Pondering what if the inevitable happened. Max was in peril SO MANY TIMES in this film. There was at least 10 times where I thought "this is the end, he's going to die" then he miraculously gets out of it. But it's not the cliche type when someone luckily comes along at the last moment and saves him. Believe me there aren't many, if any cliches in this movie. He fights his way out of these death defying situations. Furiosa out other lead is also in life threatening situations throughout this movie. Many times where we wouldn't know if she would make it.

If you don't see Mad Max: Fury Road in the theaters then you are missing out. I went in IMAX and I can tell you it was worth every goddamn penny. I don't think I'll ever be able to watch this on a TV screen not after seeing this. I expect many more viewings of this movie while it's still in theaters. Don't wait for the blu ray, don't be an asshole and illegally download it. The fact that this movie might well be outsold by Pitch Perfect 2 is very upsetting. This movie needs your money. It deserves your money. And it deserves a sequel. Give this movie the revenue it deserves. Papa wants a sequel.

There is a reason why Mad Max is called the "Road Warrior."  I will never forget this movie. I loved every scene in this movie. Thank you George Miller for bringing us a movie where we will cherish it. This movie showed us a world of mad action. 100% for this insane film. If you want a good action film, then go see this movie. It is worth your money. I hope you will agree we me after watching the movie. I know I did.
Oh, what a film. What a lovely film! Filled with non-stop action, beautiful cinematography, practical effects, Mad Max: Fury Road is the most innovative action film in a long time.

Miller's fictional world, now with a $150 million budget, is operatically mad. And the vicious marauders, crazed motorcyclists andover-the-top warlords live up to the title's accurate adjective, like Max.

I''m so disappointed in this movie...disappointed THAT I'M STILL NOT WATCHING THIS MOVIE! OH MY GOD MAD MAX IS INCREDIBLE! This is hands down the best movie of 2015 from what I've seen so far. Mad Max has a great cast with great performances from Hardy, Theron and Hoult. George Miller at 70 years old creates some of the most stunning and intense action scenes ever put to film! Mad Max Fury Road just might be one of the best action movies ever made!
Absolutely incredible, super action packed from beginning to end

I was so excited for this movie and it EXCEEDED my expectations!!!! The action scenes were so impressive and exciting, loved Tom Hardy (so handsome by the way), Charlize Theron was awesome, Nicholas Hoult was a great crazy person, the desert landscape was beautiful, I loved the random rock band on a moving truck, and the whole movie was so intense. The only small problem I had was that I wish there was a little bit more character development between some of the people but it gives you just enough to care about the people. I was never bored watching this movie. I am so ready for the sequels that they plan to do. This is an action movie done right!

Mad Max: Fury Road is..............something special. The kind of special you never expect from George Miller even after 30 years since he stopped the Mad Max films, and OH GOD DAMN, this film left a IMPRESSIVE smirk on my face. With such BEAUTIFUL practical stunts, good and well paced story, EXHILARATING action, Charlize Theron and Tom Hardy giving their most BADASS performances i've EVER seen from them, and staying VERY true to the original Mel Gibson Mad Max films with a 4th film that makes IMPRESSIVE changes on the franchise with its tone, style, and action, though the film could have cut some of its action as it does drag and could have been cut a BIT shorter. But never the less, I'd say for the first time in my years of watching films that this is the BEST 4t INSTALLMENT TO A FILM, I'VE EVER SEEN! AUTOMATICALLY going on my top ten BEST films of 2015.
Despite Mad Max is just for nerds/old people... it's awesome. Filled with breathtaking visuals and successful characters at their highest insanity level, Fury Road makes you want more.
Awesome, absolutely loved this film!

A Non-Stop Action Film that is Crazy Fun! Not much of a story and we don't really get too close to any of the film's major players. However, the cinematography, art direction, editing and array of kooky characters makes up for any of the movies short comings.

I haven't seen the original movies in a long time, and skipped the third altogether.  What I remember is few and far between, so before watching this one watched some clips and summaries to get back into it.  This movie is more like the second film than the others.  The cars are sweet.  How they made them and have them running is amazing and really takes this movie to a whole nother level.  The car crashes are some I the best in cinema in my opinion in terms or realism and effects, they look so good and are so violent it's awesome. The characters are good, Max is mysterious and doesn't talk much, and Tom Hardy does a great job playing him.  I was surprised how characters would die with such sudden violent deaths, it was nice to see and made it all the more violent and crazy.  There wasn't much for action blood or gore, but seeing the bad leaders face get torn off was pretty great.  It seems like plot is tossed aside here for action, which is a fair trade off given to result.  It's a non stop action movie where anybody could die at any time and they is always some other crazy fuel thirsty guy to jump into the fray.  There is a fair share of kinds dumb stuff as well however, like the jump onto the massive crane hook, pulling a massive truck out of a mud pit with a winch to a tree, and some of the stunts, but they are all straight up the for fun and don't really affect the fun of the movie.  The ending was ok, just kinda a ending to say the least which doesn't really make us feel anything.  But it's all about the action, which is fast paced and hectic, over the top crazy and awesome to watch.  The sound effects are loud and just make the scale of it all feel that much more massive.  Need to go back to watch the originals now, but feel like for once they aren't gonna satisfy me as much as the remake. Impressive work
Incredible!!!!!! beautiful!!!!!amazing!!!!!!magnificent!!!!!!! just plain awesome. Best action movie, ever. Mad Max Fury Road is a must see movie. Go and see it now!!!
A modern masterpiece of action films and movies overall.

This is like a great punk album exploding onto the charts and taking everyone by surprise. It's what I always wanted. The craziest big budget movie ever made. Ive never seen anything quite like it. Cheers George Miller.

Charlize Theron kicks major butt, not since Sigourney Weaver in 'Aliens' has a movie given us a heroine equal to the main hero! Tom Hardy is a perfect choice for an intense, thrill ride. "Mad Max: Fuy Road" puts other action movies to complete shame. For the action movies to come it's a disaster. Believe the hype. This movies literally holds you on the edge of your seat. I was surprised that I was still breathing at the end. 
I wasn't sure what to expect from Fury Road at first. From the trailer, the visuals looked great. Never did I expect something like this. With technical precision that seems effortless but must surely have taken a small army to manage, Miller weaves his unique, fantastic vision of post-apocalyptic chaos and carnage into a work of lunatic poetry, all set to that unbelievably furious soundtrack. The film distills cinema to its most primal elements and then sets it all on fire. I haven't seen anything remotely close to this in a long time... Fury Road actually proves that action movies can be art. It's like Cirque du Soleil of chaos. George Miller has created a new language for action movies now.
The character development is astonishingly good for a movie of that type and the whole plot is surprisingly tender. It's adventurous, edgy and wild (and mad!!) but at its core is really soft. Although we will generally remember Fury Road as an action masterpiece, it was the quieter times that this film really strikes a chord for audiences to care for its surprisingly engaging characters. The backdrop of the desolate landscape provides some of the best wide angle shots in cinematic history and the tone of the adrenaline pumping action always leave pulses of excitement and thrill for the next invigorating engagement. It delivers a rare alternative to aggressively stupid action movies.
The imagery of the film is both surreal and imaginative. I acknowledge that some set and character designs may not be for everyone's taste but one cannot deny that George Miller has a daring vision for his films. With total confidence, the film exists in its own world without the need to tiresomely weigh down the story with back story or explanations. From the very first scenes, its beauty is captivating. 
Tom Hardy is good but it's Charlize Theron who really owns the film!
Overall, I felt the film to be a call back to the old days when people came to cinemas to have an experience. To have an opportunity to see something truly special. Mad Max is certainly such a ride. This is a definite must-see (and a worthy one in 3-D too).
I personally think that theaters should get seatbelts installed for Fury Road!

Equal to the hype. Balls to the wall.

In 2011 a leaked image of Tom Hardy as Mad Max took the Internet by storm and garnered the attention of myself, someone who has dearly loved the Mad Max franchise since I was a small child. 

This film has been a long time coming and I am happy to report that it does not disappoint. My expectations were high going in, but I hoped only to see a return to the Road Warrior aesthetic of intense chases and senseless action. Instead, George Miller delivered a masterpiece that not only puts all other action films to shame but also weaves a plausible plot that surely made a film that is friendly to anyone who is willing to give it a chance. 

I could go on, needing to discuss the success of Miller's female characters as well but that is for another time.

"What a Lovely Day!"

Even at the beginning, there's no hint MAD MAX: FURY ROAD is going to a stop. Right at the very start, the engines are already rewing, gathering furious fires of vengeance and redemption, and before the audience could snap out of the sheer moments of brutal grittiness and exhilarating high-octane drama, they are surely already held hostage within the confines of a post-apocalyptic world, where everything is horrendously scarce. Not that it's a bad thing, no it's not. I tell you, this is like being hurled into the space in a roller-coaster ride. It's dangerous, but it's also thrilling. Witnessing this dystopic world and all its hellish drama unfold might make you grope for seatbelt under your seat.

The film shares Max Rockatansky's (Tom Hardy) adventures. Max is an ex highway patrolman. He's been haunted by the past, by family he never saved. He meets the Imperator Furiosa (Charlize Theron) who is being pursued by the dictatorial Wasteland leader "Joe". Furiosa reaches for Max for help in keeping the 'Five Wives'-women she brought with her-into safety, as Joe's deranged breed of warriors called The War Boys, that are barely humans, are raging across the desert to capture them. This pursuit throws the unlikely partners into the whalloping dangers of bloody escape, suddenly sending them into a game of survival.

After a rip-roaring opening chase sequence, Max is held captive in the Citadel, the city where the ruthlessly totalitarian leader "Joe" is ruling over. The grotesquely brutal lord maintains tight grip of every valuable resouces across the land. This brings the entire populace crippling under his control. As for Max, he becomes merely a blood bag for Nux (Nick Hoult) one of Joe's War Boys, who is a fatal devout to the cause of their fascist leader, who has promised them the glory of getting into Valhalla, the promised land.

Everything in this cinematic behemoth screams grandeur, even the feverish chase, even the dark erubescents spurred from the ruthless violence. Miller has molded a world where darkness is an escape from the stream of clich√©s and retreads, surging into the cinemas, today. It's a visual feast, but surprisingly, with sense. It's explosive in every unimaginable ways, but it's not devoid of a human story, which in this case, is propelled by stellar performances from incredible actors on the movie's payroll. Tom Hardy is utterly capable as the main hero, but the emotional spine of the narrative mostly runs on Theron's character. At some point, there would be a sense that Max isn't the only one playing under the spotlight, as it gets evident Furiosa is equally as massive as his role is. Hardy here is singularly stunning, playing his role with utmost credibility as he is required. His mission transcends past his emotional torments and he's never pulled himself free from the ghosts if his past. Same can be said with Furiosa, who is not only running from Joe because she wants to get herself free from his cut throat grip, but also to bring every woman into safety, back to freedom where they belong.

Much of the movie is spent with furious speed chases that goes from end to end of Joe's subjugated land, while also taking surprising twists and turns along the way. It's like it doesn't know how to stop, and if it does, that's surely only to allow us breathe and catch up with the next electrifying action setpiece. There's an enigmatic style Miller has employed to provide distinctions in his fantasy world, and it keeps the momentum in tack, if not ever progressing. The tone of the movie, all those vividly dark colors, that magically shifts from something to another, imparts a drowning experience, only it's enjoying and looks festive to the eyes. This makes every eye-squashing spectacles take mammoth forms of visual extravaganza, turning all those burning combustions, metal blasts, and endless pursuits, from mere technical marvels into a hair-raising escapade.

Amid these sanity-grabbing action sequences, though, is an emotional streak that keeps Max and Furiousa's humanity alive. This prompts them to survival, into carrying out their similar humane causes, clinging tightly to their only mission even if they get hurled into the barbaric hostilities of their dystopian society. This turns the movie into something visceral, cathartic in some ways that probably only a small fraction of the audience could understand. It will not be enough to merit this achievement with merely a splurge of superlatives. This needs to be experienced, felt, and forever cherished. MAD MAX: FURY ROAD, ignites eternal fire, and it will keep burning through the stretches of cinematic history.

Rarely a film of such epic scale has come with so much anticipation and mystery all at once. The long delayed George Miller 's fourth Mad Max film in the franchise is finally hitting the screens and let me tell you, the 30 years gap between Thunderdome and Furry Road was well worth the wait. The film is actually more a reboot than a sequel and it's maybe for the best. Mastermind G. Miller is back with the most incredible slice of dystopian madness you'll ever experience at the movies these days. When everything look and feel the same with avalanche of CGI and total lack of depth, Miller manages to give his film not only heart and guts but a look absolutely unique and beyond anything I have seen so far. Combining the best of technology and old school film making this new episode of the adventure of the lone desert 'Samurai' has a taste of madness like you will rarely see. Inspired by paintings of Dali and Goya for the visuals and probably a few more, the film plays like a massive chase across the desert, restless and uncompromising, nightmarish as hell but gorgeous as can be. Many themes are tackled along the chase and Miller seems to have understood a long time ago that men are beasts with no real future unless women take control and bring back the necessary balance our world needs if we wish to survive and have a future. The character of Furiosa is shown as an equal to Max and some scenes show them looking very similar to each-others, both broken and desperate for redemption. This films manages to bring back the old school adventure flick, a no brainer on the outside but with a lot of depth if you look closer. Miller is a genius on his own, shots after shots he builds a tension of a rare intensity and manages to offer to his audience a film that will definitely surprise a lot of people through it's unusual pace, messages and visuals. The soundtrack is amazing with a lot of percussions during the chases across the desert, pushing the madness as to have a group of drummers playing on the rooftop of a truck and a heavy metal player blasting his flame thrower guitar while chained to one of the trucks. By now you have figured out that you are dealing with a film like no others, filled with images from another world. It will take me a few days to recover from the experience because i haven't been thrilled by a film this much since El Topo of legendary director A. Jodorowski. By now all hope is for another episode soon, a Mad Max: Furiosa would be quite thrilling, let's only hope mister Georgy won't wait 30 years this time... (BTW did i mention that i have seen the film 11 times in all the movie theaters of the Bay Area? You are a fan or a foe...)
